article: Many years ago, a 10--year--old boy walked into a soda shop. He asked the  _  , "How much is an ice cream sundae ?" "Fifty cents," the waitress replied. The boy  _  into his pockets, pulled out a handful of change and began counting. The waitress looked at the boy impatiently.  After all  , she had other customers to wait on. After counting, the boy asked the waitress again, " How much is a dish of plain ice cream? " "Thirty-five cents, " the waitress said a little  _  . Again the boy counted his coins. At last, he said, "I'II have the plain ice cream please. " He put 35 cents  _  the counter . The waitress took the coins, brought the ice cream and walked away. About ten minutes later, she retumed and found the ice cream dish  _  . The boy was gone. She  picked up  the empty dish--then she was surprised. There on the counter, next to the wet spot where the dish had been, were 15 cents. The boy had  enough  . money for a sundae, but he had ordered plain ice cream  _  he could leave her a tip. In a world that tells us to "get  _  we can" , every so often it's good to be reminded to "give something. away".
